author: Liam Hyslop
title: Trent Boult the million-dollar man at IPL auction as Ben Stokes breaks record
text:
Trent Boult the million-dollar man at IPL auction as Ben Stokes breaks record LIAM HYSLOP Last updated 19:01, February 20 2017 ANDREW CORNAGA/PHOTOSPORT 
Blackcaps paceman Trent Boult will play for the Kolkata Knight Riders in the IPL after going for more than $1 million in the auction. 
Trent Boult will be a happy man after being sold for more than $1 million at the Indian Premier League auction. 
The 27-year-old New Zealand fast bowler was the subject of a bidding duel on Monday between the Kolkata Knight Riders and Mumbai Indians before the former got their man for five crore rupees (NZ$1.04m). 
That figure does not necessarily indicate what his salary will be. Players are paid pro-rata based on how many games they play. ANDREW CORNAGA/PHOTOSPORT 
Trent Boult will be all smiles after going for more than $1 million at the IPL auction. 
It was the second-highest price paid for a New Zealand player in the IPL. Brendon McCullum got 7.5 crore rupees ($1.56m) in 2015 when drafted by the team now known as the Gujarat Lions. Ross Taylor went for 4.6 crore rupees ($950,000) in 2011. 
READ MORE: 
Boult's Blackcaps team-mate Corey Anderson was the only other Kiwi to be picked up in the early action when sold for his reserve price of $208,000 to the Delhi Daredevils. REUTERS 
Corey Anderson was picked up by the Delhi Daredevils at the IPL auction. 
The news was not as good for batsmen Martin Guptill and Taylor, who were among the early players in the auction, but failed to attract any bids. Players that aren't initially sold go to a secondary auction, so the pair may get picked up at that point. 
It was the second year in a row Guptill missed out, although this year was not as surprising as last year when he was in the white ball form of his life. 
There was no love either for Kiwi legspinner Ish Sodhi. Fourteen other New Zealanders will go under the hammer later in the auction. ANDREW CORNAGA/PHOTOSPORT 
Blackcaps batsman Ross Taylor failed to attract a bid at the Indian Premier League auction. 
Earlier, Englishman Ben Stokes fetched the highest ever price for an overseas player at the Indian Premier League auction. Ad Feedback 
New Zealand coach Stephen Fleming and his Rising Pune Supergiants team went to 14.5 crore, more than $3 million, for the allrounder, despite the fact he will probably miss the knockout stage of the tournament for England's tour of South Africa. 
He was just short of the record for a player at the auction. That was Indian star Yuvraj Singh, who went for 16 crore to the Delhi Daredevils in 2015. ANDREW CORNAGA/PHOTOSPORT 
The Indian Premier League teams passed up in Martin Guptill at the auction. 
Another Kiwi coach got his wallet out a short time later. Daniel Vettori spent 12 crore rupees ($2.5m) for English paceman Tymal Mills to play for his Royal Challengers Bangalore side in what was thought to be the highest ever price paid for a bowler. 
At the start of the auction there were just 29 overseas spots remaining, with 125 players, including 19 New Zealanders, vying for those at auction. 
The eight franchises retained 140 players including five New Zealanders: Kane Williamson (Sunrisers), Brendon McCullum (Gujarat Lions), Southee and Mitchell McClenaghan (Mumbai) and Adam Milne (Bangalore). REUTERS 
England's Ben Stokes attracted the highest ever bid for a player at the Indian Premier League auction. 
AT A GLANCE 
Kiwis at the IPL auction 
SOLD: Trent Boult to Kolkata Knight Riders for $1.04 million; Corey Anderson to Delhi Daredevils for $208,000. 
UNSOLD: Martin Guptill, Ross Taylor, Ish Sodhi. - Stuff
